'''Sortes''' ([[Latin]] singular: ''sors'') were a frequent method of [[divination]] among the [[ancient Rome|ancient Romans]].<ref name="DGRA">{{Citation | last = Smith | first = William | author-link = William Smith (lexicographer) | contribution = Sortes | editor-last = Smith | editor-first = William | title = [[Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquities]] | volume = 1 | pages = 1051–1052 | publisher = [[Little, Brown and Company]] | place = Boston | year = 1870 | contribution-url = http://www.ancientlibrary.com/smith-dgra/1058.html }}</ref> The method involved the [[Cleromancy|drawing of lots]] (''sortes'') to obtain knowledge of future events: in many of the ancient Italian temples the will of the gods was consulted in this way, as at [[Praeneste]] and [[Caere]].<ref>Regarding the meaning of ''sors'' see [[Cicero]], ''[[De Divinatione]]'' ii. 41</ref>
These ''sortes'' or lots were usually little tablets or counters, made of wood or other materials, and were commonly thrown into a [[Situla (vessel)|sitella or urn]], filled with water. The lots were sometimes thrown like dice.<ref>[[Suetonius]], ''Tiberius'' 14</ref> The name of "sortes" was in fact given to anything used to determine chances,<ref>compare [[Cicero]], ''[[De Divinatione]]'' i. 34</ref> and was also applied to any verbal response of an oracle.<ref>[[Cicero]], ''[[De Divinatione]]'' ii. 56 and [[Virgil]], ''[[Aeneid]]'' iv. 346, 377</ref>
Various things were written upon the lots according to circumstances, as for instance the names of the persons using them. It seems to have been a favorite practice in later times to write the verses of illustrious poets upon little tablets, and to draw them out of the urn like other lots, the verses which a person thus obtained being supposed to be applicable to him (see ''[[Sortes Homerica]]'' and ''[[Sortes Virgilianae]]'', lots created from verses of [[Homer]] and [[Virgil]]).<ref>Mentioned by [[Aelius Lampridius|Lampridius]], ''Alex. Sever.'' 14 and [[Spartianus]], ''Hadr.'' 2</ref>
In the [[Bible|Biblical]] account of the prophet [[Jonah]], he is thrown into the sea and swallowed by the fish after the sailors on the ship cast lots to determine the guilty one who had brought about the storm.<ref>Jonah 1:7</ref> It was also the practice to consult the poets in the same way as [[Islam|Muslims]] do the [[Koran]] and [[Hafiz (Qur'an)|Hafiz]], and many [[Christian]]s the [[Bible]], namely, by opening the book at random and applying the first passage that struck the eye to a person's own immediate circumstances.<ref>[[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]], ''Confessions'' iv. 3</ref> This practice was very common among the [[early Christians]], who substituted the Bible and the [[Psalter]] for [[Homer]] and [[Virgil]]. Many church councils repeatedly condemned these ''[[Sortes Sanctorum]]'' (sacred lots), as they were called.<ref>[[Edward Gibbon]], ''[[The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire]]'', c. xxxviii. note 51</ref>
The [[Sibylline books]] were probably also consulted in this way. Those who foretold future events by lots were called ''Sortilegi''.<ref>[[Marcus Annaeus Lucanus|Lucan]], ix. 581</ref>
The ''sortes convivales'' were sealed tablets, which were sold at entertainments, and upon being opened or unsealed entitled the purchaser to things of very unequal value. They were therefore a kind of [[lottery]].<ref>[[Suetonius]], ''Octav.'' 75 and Lampridius, ''Heliogab.'' 22</ref>
==See also== *''[[Sortes Astrampsychi]]'' *[[Cleromancy]] *[[Bibliomancy]] *[[Rhapsodomancy]]

{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox building |name = Sydney Bahá'í Temple |image = Bahaitemplesydney.JPG |caption = |building_type = [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] |architectural_style = |structural_system = |location = [[Ingleside, New South Wales|Ingleside]], Sydney, Australia |map_type = |map_caption = |coordinates = {{coord|-33.6855|151.2587|display=inline,title}} |completion_date = 16 September 1961 |opened = |capacity = 600 |diameter = {{convert|20|m}} |height = {{convert|38|m}} |main_contractors = |architect = [[Mason Remey]], John Brogan |structural_engineer = }}
The '''Sydney Bahá'í House of Worship''' or '''Sydney Bahá'í Temple''' is situated in [[Ingleside, New South Wales|Ingleside]], a northern suburb of Sydney, Australia.<ref name="iranica">{{cite encyclopedia | last = Rafati | first = V. | author2-last = Sahba | author2-first = F. | author2-link = Fariborz Sahba | editor-last = Yarshater | editor-first = Ehsan | title = BAHAISM ix. Bahai Temples | encyclopedia = Encyclopaedia Iranica | volume = 3 | pages = 465–467 | location = New York |year = 1996 | edition = Online | url = http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/bahaism-ix | accessdate = 24 December 2016}}</ref> According to [[Jennifer Taylor (architect)|Jennifer Taylor]], a historian at [[Sydney University]], it is among Sydney's four most significant religious buildings constructed in the twentieth century.<ref name="dict-syd">{{cite web|last1=Dictionary of Sydney staff writer|title=Baha'i House of Worship|url=http://dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/bahai_house_of_worship|website=Dictionary of Sydney|accessdate=13 January 2017}}</ref> It was the world's fourth [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] to be constructed, completed in 1961.<ref name="iranica"/> [[Shoghi Effendi]], head of the [[Bahá'í Faith]] when the House of Worship was designed, called it the "Mother Temple of the whole Pacific area" and the "Mother Temple of the [[Antipodes]]."<ref name="bahai-encyc">{{cite web|last1=Badiee|first1=Julie and the Editors|title=Mashriqu'l-Adhkár|url=http://www.bahai-encyclopedia-project.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=70:mashriqul-adhkar&catid=36:administrationinstitutions#sydney|website=The Bahá'i Encyclopedia Project|accessdate=14 January 2017}}</ref> Every year, over 20,000 domestic and foreign visitors frequent the House of Worship.<ref name="bahai-encyc"/>
==History== In the early 1950s, the [[Bahá'í Faith in Australia|Bahá'ís of Australia]] began work to purchase a property for a House of Worship.<ref name="herald">{{cite web|last1=Hassall|first1=Graham|title=The Bahá'í Faith in Australia: 75 Years Remembered|url=http://bahai-library.com/pdf/h/hassall_75_years_australia.pdf|publisher=Herald of the South|accessdate=14 January 2017}}</ref> When the [[persecution of Bahá'ís]] intensified in [[Iran]] in 1955, Shoghi Effendi, then head of the religion, suspended plans for a House of Worship in [[Tehran]] and commissioned two others in its place, one in [[Kampala]], [[Uganda]], and the other in Sydney.<ref name="jrh-hassall">{{cite journal|last1=Hassall|first1=Graham|title=The Bahá'í Faith in Australia 1947–1963|journal=Journal of Religious History|date=December 2012|volume=36|issue=4|pages=563–576|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9809.2012.01231.x|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jorh.2012.36.issue-4/issuetoc|accessdate=14 January 2017}}</ref> The property for the temple was acquired in 1956.<ref name="jrh-hassall"/> An initial design by [[Mason Remey|Charles Mason Remey]] was given to Sydney architect John Brogan to develop and complete, and construction began in April 1957.<ref name="dict-syd"/> On 22 March 1958, a foundation ceremony was held which was attended by Clara Dunn, a [[Hand of the Cause]] appointed by Shoghi Effendi who first brought the Bahá'í Faith to Australia in 1920 along with her husband John Hyde Dunn.<ref name="bahai-encyc"/>
The temple was dedicated on 16 and 17 September 1961<ref name="bahai-encyc"/> by Shoghi Effendi's widow [[Rúhíyyih Khánum]] (Mary Maxwell),<ref name="univ-local">{{cite encyclopedia|last=Hassall|first=Graham|editor1-last=Cusack|editor1-first=Carole M.|editor1-link=Carole M. Cusack|editor2-last=Norman|editor2-first=Alex|encyclopedia=Handbook of New Religions and Cultural Production|title=The Bahá'í House of Worship: Localization and universal form|year=2012|publisher=Brill Publishers|location=Leiden, Nerthelands|isbn=9789004221871|url=https://www.academia.edu/467801/The_Bah%C3%A1%C3%AD_House_of_Worship_Localization_and_universal_form|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref> and international dignitaries then attended a reception hosted by the [[mayor of Sydney]].<ref name="jrh-hassall"/> At this time, the structure's technical features received treatment in engineering and construction journals including ''Plywood and Products'' and ''Construction'', while general coverage appeared in [[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|''The Daily Telegraph'']], [[The Daily Mirror (Sydney)|''The Daily Mirror'']], ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'', and ''The Australian Post'', among other Australian news outlets.<ref name="pre-encycl">{{cite web|last1=Hassall|first1=Graham|title=Australia: History of the Bahá'í Faith|url=http://bahai-library.com/hassall_bahai_faith_australia|website=Bahá'í Library Online|accessdate=14 January 2017|year=1998}}</ref> Internationally, the temple was mentioned briefly in sources including ''[[The Economist]]'' and ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''.<ref name="jrh-hassall"/> The total cost of the four-year construction was £175,000.<ref name="univ-local"/>
In the summer of 1993–1994<ref name="herald"/> and again in 2005–2006, the temple was threatened by nearby bush fires which approached but never reached the temple grounds.<ref name="dict-syd"/> In 2011, a week of events was held to mark the temple's fiftieth anniversary, including an interfaith prayer service, a reception attended by dignitaries such as the [[Premier of New South Wales]], and an exhibition featuring children's art on creating a more peaceful world.<ref name="50anniv">{{cite web|title=Australian society 'enriched and ennobled' by Baha'i temple|url=http://news.bahai.org/story/851|publisher=Bahá'í World News Service|accessdate=7 February 2017|date=22 September 2011}}</ref>
==Building and grounds== [[File:Bahai temple sydney.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Interior of the Bahá'í House of Worship]] On the ground floor of the temple is a main auditorium with seating for six hundred people, encircled by a gallery.<ref name="univ-local"/> From there, nine doors open onto the grounds at equal angles, as in all Bahá'í Houses of Worship, signifying the [[Bahá'í Faith and the unity of religion|unity of the world's religions]].<ref name="dict-syd"/> The second level features windows of [[Palladian architecture|Palladian style]] that illuminate the building's interior.<ref name="bahai-encyc"/> A ribbed [[dome]] rises above them, spanning 20 metres horizontally and reaching 38 metres above ground level at its highest point.<ref name="bahai-encyc"/><ref name="univ-local"/> There is a lantern perched on top of the dome, which was placed there by a helicopter during the construction.<ref name="bahai-encyc"/> Construction materials include crushed quartz,<ref name="bahai-encyc"/> local hardwoods in the interior,<ref name="dict-syd"/> and concrete and marble in the dome.<ref name="jrh-hassall"/>
The temple is a highly visible landmark<ref name="univ-local"/> as it occupies the highest point above Sydney's [[Northern Beaches]] region,<ref name="dict-syd"/> overlooking the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] coast<ref name="univ-local"/> at [[Mona Vale, New South Wales|Mona Vale]].<ref name="jrh-hassall"/> It is on [[Mona Vale Road]],<ref name="dict-syd"/> set in an area of natural bushland included in an [[Indigenous Protected Area]].<ref name="univ-local"/> The surrounding gardens contain a variety of native [[Flora of Australia|Australian flora]] including [[Telopea speciosissima|waratahs]], three species of [[eucalypt]]s, [[Grevillea caleyi|caleyi]] and other [[grevillea]], [[acacia]], and [[Xylomelum|woody pear]].<ref name="univ-local"/> Other amenities located on the site include a visitors' centre, a bookshop, a picnic area, and the administrative offices of the Australian Bahá'í community.<ref name="bahai-encyc"/> When the number of Australian Bahá'ís becomes sufficient to sustain them, humanitarian centres for education, welfare, and other purposes will be established around the temple.<ref name="encyc-hassall">{{cite encyclopedia|last=Hassall|first=Graham|editor-last=Jupp|editor-first=James|editor-link=James Jupp|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Religion in Australia|title=The Bahá'í Faith|year=2009|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=9780521864077|pages=168–171|url=http://bahai-library.com/hassall_encyclopedia_religion_australia|accessdate=14 January 2017}}</ref>
==Worship== The [[Bahá'í Faith]] teaches that a [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] should be a space for people of all religions to gather, reflect, and worship.<ref name="iranica"/><ref name="encyc-hassall"/> As is the case with all Bahá'í Houses of Worship, anyone may enter the Sydney temple irrespective of religious background, sex, or other distinctions.<ref name="iranica"/> The [[Religious texts|sacred writings]] of not only the Bahá'í Faith but also other religions can be read and/or chanted, regardless of language;<ref name="iranica"/> on the other hand, reading non-scriptural texts is forbidden, as are delivering [[sermon]]s or lectures and fundraising.<ref name="encyc-hassall"/> Musical renditions of readings and prayers can be sung by choirs but no musical instruments can be played inside.<ref name="encyc-hassall"/> There is no set pattern for worship services, and ritualistic ceremonies are not permitted.<ref name="iranica"/><ref name="encyc-hassall"/>
On Sundays and on [[Bahá'í Holy Days]], public prayer services are held with readings from the sacred texts of various religions and [[a cappella]] music sung by the temple choir.<ref name="dict-syd"/>

'''''The Crescent''''' newspaper was re-launched in 2018 as an [[Electronic newspaper|electronic web based newspaper]] initially published monthly for the pilot and subsequent issues and this was reduced to weekly every Friday thereafter . The [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] 12 page format launched in 2003 failed due to the massive overheads of printing and distributing community based paper, it was decided to take advantage of the latest developments in [[Electronic publishing|e-publishing]] and re-launch the paper as an electronic web based publication. The Crescent newspaper is an independent [[Community media|community based publication]] and encourages and promotes independent editorial comment and news content. It draws on communal journalistic resources in a broader sense if the definition from across the British Isles and Eire, but is not confined by the perceived definition of [[Community journalism|Community Journalism]]. It is a young English, Irish, Scottish, and Welsh Muslim publication, regardless of [[Ethnic_origin | ethnic origin]] to provide a different media narrative for a global [[English-speaking_world | English speaking]] readership. == History == '''1893''' to '''1908'''
[[File:The Crescent 1st edition.jpg|thumb|left|'''''The Crescent''''' 1st edition
14 January 1893 vol. 1 no. 1]] [[File:The Crescent newspaper a weekly record of Islam in England.JPG|smallpx|thumbnail|right|'''''The Crescent''''' vol. 16 no. 420
30 January 1901]] ''The Crescent - a weekly record of Islam in England''British Newspaper Library ref: BLL01013898565 Title: The Crescent : (A weekly record of Islam in England) was originally published weekly in Liverpool from 1893. As such, it can claim to be oldest and first regular publication reflecting and serving the early convertConvert is the English word most often used for one who embraces a religion after being raised in another faith. A common definition of the word "convert" is to "change from one religion or belief to another." A person is considered to have converted to Islam from the moment he or she sincerely makes this declaration of faith, called the ''shahadah'', and this declaration encompasses their acceptance and belief in the five pillars, or foundations, of Islam and that there is only one God and Creator, referred to as Allah (the word for the name of God in Arabic) and that the Islamic prophet, Muhammad, is His last and final messenger. Converts are sometimes referred to as Reverts as Muslim teaching holds that everyone is Muslim at birth because every child that is born has a natural inclination to goodness and to worship the one true God alone, but his or her parents or society can cause him or her to deviate from the straight path. When someone accepts Islam he/she is considered to revert to his/her original condition. and Muslim community within the British Isles, although its readership quickly grew via subscription to a global community. The first edition was published on 14 January 1893 from 32 Elizabeth Street,Elizabeth Street now forms part of the Faculty of Medicine at Liverpool University, but his father, Robert Henry Quilliam, a successful watchmaker, was trading from the premises under his father's name Samuel Quilliam Liverpool, shortly before moving to Brougham Terrace. It was edited by [http://abdullahquilliam.com/ W.H. Abdullah Quilliam] and represented Muslims in England and growing convert community between 1893 and 1908. A statement in ''The Crescent'' to its advertisers''The Crescent'' - statement to advertisers in the last edition published on 28 May 1908 from Geneva Road, Liverpool. declared that “''in addition to the thousands of copies in circulation within the British Isles, in addition to which thousands of copies of the Paper are sent regularly abroad to subscribers in France, Spain, Switzerland, Constantinople, Smyrna, Syria, Turkey in Asia, Russia, Morocco, Tunis, Algeria, Malta, Egypt, Persia, Beluchistan, Ceylon, Arabia, the Cape Colony, the Transvaal, Zanzibar, Lagos, Gambia, Sierra Leone, the west Coast of Africa, Afghanistan, Penang, Singapore, China, British Guiana, Trinidad, Canada, the United States of America, and many parts of India, this forming a capital advertising medium''”. The advertising rate was stated as being 2s. 6d.2s. 6d. (two shillings and sixpence, or half a crown) equates to 12.5 pence decimal per inch per insertion. After outgrowing the Muslim prayer hall established by Quilliam in Mount Vernon, Liverpool, in 1888 he rented 8 Brougham Terrace[http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-359729-brougham-terrace-8-9-and-10-liverpool 8 Brougham Terrace] and also acquired the neighbouring properties, numbers 10 and 12 in 1889, and in the basement a printing press was established to produce the monthly editions of ''The Islamic World'',''The Islamic World'' - an intermittent monthly publication from 1889 which preceded ''The Crescent'' - ref: ''Islam in Victorian Britain: The Life and Times of Abdullah Quilliam'' {{ISBN|1847740103}} which was subscribed to globally. In 1893, it evolved into the weekly publication ''The Crescent - a weekly record of Islam in England''. Plans were announced for a purpose-built mosque to be built to the design of J. H. McGovern''The Crescent'' - article 28 March 1900 – ''Proposed mosque in Liverpool''. J.H. McGovern had provided architectural detailed plans for the proposed mosque at the new site and these plans were forwarded to Quilliam in Istanbul in 1898, so that he could submit them to the Sultan, Abdul Hamid II for approval and financial assistance. on the site of 10 and 12 [http://www.bbc.co.uk/legacies/heritage/england/liverpool/article_1.shtml Brougham Terrace], but did not materialise, any more than did those of 1902, for a mosque in the communities new centre at Geneva Road, Elm Park, Liverpool where ''The Crescent'' continued to be published until May 1908. ''The Crescent'' newspaper is a social history of a growing Muslim convert community. Such names as Yahya McQuinn, T. Omar Byrne, [http://www.masud.co.uk/ISLAM/bmh/BMH-fatimacates.htm Fatima Cates], [https://medium.com/@yahyabirt/abdullah-quilliams-obituary-of-yahya-parkinson-1874-1918-697ab7b4df9 Yahya Nasser Parkinson], Nasrullah Warren, J. Bokhari Jeffery, and Omar Roberts appear regularly in the editorial, but the wider community would include [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Stanley,_3rd_Baron_Stanley_of_Alderley Henry, Lord Stanley of Alderly], Hasan El-Arculli a Muslim G.P. and many others. ==2018 to present== The Crescent Newspaper was relaunched in 1440 A.H. (September 2018) by British Muslim converts residing in UK and Eire as an [[Online newspaper|on-line newspaper]] with the title '[http://www.thecrescent.online ''The Crescent'' newspaper]'. It appears as both printedBritish Library ref: '''ISSN 2517-4975''' - printed edition and on-lineBritish Library ref: '''ISSN 2517-4983''' - electronic edition editions. It is planned to publish the paper monthly on the first Friday of each month from the first Friday of the Muslim New Year in MuharremMuharram (Arabic: المحرّم) is the first month of the Islamic calendar and marks the start of the Islamic new year. 1440, and move to a fortnightly publication thereafter. == Regular content and features == * UK News * World News * News Briefs * People - Demos, Odds and Ends|other uses|To the Stars (disambiguation)}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox album | name = To the Stars | type = studio | artist = [[Chick Corea Elektric Band]] | cover = 2004 Chick Corea Elektric Bank To the Stars.jpg | alt = | released = August 24, 2004 | recorded = 2004 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Jazz fusion]], [[post-bop]] | length = 68:16 | label = [[Stretch Records|Stretch]] | producer = [[Chick Corea]] | prev_title = [[Elektric Band II: Paint the World]] | prev_year = 1993 | next_title = [[The Ultimate Adventure]] | next_year = 2006 }} '''''To the Stars''''' is an album by American [[jazz fusion]] group the [[Chick Corea Elektric Band]], released on August 24, 2004 by [[Stretch Records]]. [[Jazz]] musician [[Chick Corea]], a longtime member of the [[Church of Scientology]], was inspired by [[Scientology]] founder [[L. Ron Hubbard]]'s [[science fiction]] 1954 novel ''[[To the Stars (novel)|To the Stars]]''. Hubbard's book tells the story of an interstellar crew which experiences the effects of [[time dilation]] due to traveling at near [[Speed of light|light speed]]. A few days experienced by the ship's crew could amount to hundreds of years for their friends and family back on Earth.
Corea was influenced in particular by a scene from Hubbard's work where one of the main characters plays the piano, and he created the album as a [[tone poem]] piece. It was the first time members of his group Chick Corea Elektric Band had gotten together since 1991. Scientology-owned [[Galaxy Press]] reissued the book at the same time as the album's release as a form of [[marketing co-operation|cross-marketing]]. Corea later produced another album, ''[[The Ultimate Adventure]]'', also inspired by and named after a work by Hubbard.
The album received mostly positive reviews. Christopher Blagg of the ''[[Boston Herald]]'' commented: "Somewhere L. Ron Hubbard was smiling," and Mike Hobart of the ''[[Financial Times]]'' described the album as "a fine programme of jazz-fusion". It reached number eight on the U.S. [[Top Contemporary Jazz]] charts in September 2004, and garnered Corea a 2004 [[Grammy Award]] nomination for instrumental arrangement for the track "The Long Passage".
==Inspiration== {{main|To the Stars (novel)}}
Hubbard's ''To the Stars'' depicts a future where an interstellar ship travelling at near [[Speed of light|light speed]] slows down time experienced for its occupants.<ref name="himes" /> The ship's members are affected by [[Albert Einstein]]'s [[time dilation]] theory, and the Earth experiences hundreds of years while only a few days have passed for members of the ship.<ref name="collins">{{cite web|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=504861|work=[[The Harvard Crimson]]|title=Elektric Band and Chick Corea Resynergize: Jazz great teams up with old band for tour, album with sci-fi literary influence|publisher=The Harvard Crimson, Inc.|accessdate=2008-06-06|date=December 3, 2004|last=Collins|first=James F.}}</ref> The crew have no family or friends on Earth due to the time that separates them.<ref name="collins" /> Of the album's 17 tracks, 10 are directly based on characters or concepts from the book.<ref name="cober" /> The protagonist of the book (scientist Alan Corday), the ship's captain (Captain Jocelyn), and the ship's name (''Hound of Heaven'') are all titles of tracks on the album.<ref name="himes" /> The other seven tracks are "Port Views", short musical interludes between the larger pieces.<ref name="cober" />
Corea explains at his website how he was motivated to work on music inspired by ''To the Stars'', commenting that he was inspired by a scene from the book in which Hubbard describes the Captain of the spaceship in the story playing a melody on a piano.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chickcorea.com/to_the_stars.html|work=Chick Corea - Official Website|title="To The Stars" - The Chick Corea Elektric Band|publisher=www.chickcorea.com|accessdate=2008-06-05|last=Smith|first=Christopher |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080329091001/http://www.chickcorea.com/to_the_stars.html |archivedate = March 29, 2008}}</ref> He had read the book eight or nine times,<ref name="young">{{cite news | last =Young | first =Bob | title = MUSIC - Sci-fi on the hi-fi - Chick Corea in interstellar overdrive after inspiration from L. Ron Hubbard's works | work =[[Boston Herald]] | date =November 20, 2004 }}</ref> and after writing down musical composition based on Hubbard's work the album was created as a [[tone poem]] piece.<ref name="collins" /> Previous tone poem albums by Corea include ''The Leprechaun'' (1975), ''My Spanish Heart'' (1976), and ''The Mad Hatter'' (1978).<ref name="weideman" /> The piece is Corea's first attempt at musical interpretation from one of Hubbard's works.<ref name="collins" />
"The attraction to me was not only the challenge of writing music portraying characters in a fiction book but the fact that I've had such an intimate connection with L. Ron Hubbard and his work in Scientology for 40 years now. I've been a fan of his fiction for 25 years, and once I started into the act of working with his creations, it had an extra special excitement to me," he said in an interview with ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref name="harrington" /> "Aside from the content in his message, and the fact that he's the founder of the Church of Scientology and Dianetics, the thing I loved about Hubbard was the aesthetics of his writing. There is a musical wavelength to what he does," said Corea to ''[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]''.<ref name="gilbert" />
==Production== Corea brought together the original members of Chick Corea Elektric Band for the first time since 1991, including bassist [[John Patitucci]], drummer [[Dave Weckl]], [[saxophone|saxophonist]] [[Eric Marienthal]] and guitarist [[Frank Gambale]].<ref name="himes">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A60024-2004Nov18.html|title=CHICK COREA ELEKTRIC BAND "To the Stars" Stretch/Concord|work=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[The Washington Post Company]]|accessdate=2008-06-06|date=November 19, 2004 |page=WE07 |last=Himes |first=Geoffrey}}</ref> Gambale's electric guitar playing figures prominently in some of the tracks.<ref name="himes" /> In a statement in ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]'', Corea commented that ''To the Stars'' represented a synergy of his three greatest passions: "My passion as a composer/performer, my passion for the Elektric Band as a perfect orchestra, and my passion for L. Ron Hubbard as the ideal artist."<ref name="collins" /> The album is his "favorite recording" out of his almost one hundred album discography.<ref name="collins" />
Mike Manoogian designed the cover and book design for the 2004 hardcover edition of the novel ''To the Stars'', and the artwork is copyrighted by the [[L. Ron Hubbard Library]].<ref>{{cite book | last =Hubbard | first =L. Ron | authorlink =L. Ron Hubbard | title =[[To the Stars (novel)|To the Stars]] | publisher =[[Galaxy Press]] | date =2004 | location =[[Hollywood, Los Angeles, California|Hollywood]] | page =210 | isbn = 1-59212-175-6}}</ref> The album cover uses the same design as the novel.
The novel ''To the Stars'' was reissued by Scientology-owned Galaxy Press at the same time as the album as a form of [[cross-marketing]].<ref name="ratliff" /><ref name="Eglash">{{cite web |last1=Eglash |first1=Ruth |title=Who was L. Ron Hubbard? |url=https://www.jpost.com/Magazine/Features/Who-was-L-Ron-Hubbard |website=The Jerusalem Post |accessdate=30 August 2018 |date=7 December 2006}}</ref> According to ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'', Corea's soundtrack to the novel was issued by Galaxy Press to give the company's "enormous marketing muscle" the ability to "tap into the vast Hubbard fan base".<ref name="publishersweekly2004">{{cite journal | last =Staff | title =To the Stars | journal =[[Publishers Weekly]] | volume =251 | issue =35 | page =37 | publisher =[[Reed Business Information]] | date =August 30, 2004 }}</ref>
Corea's 2004 piece "The Adventures of Hippocrates" was inspired by a robotlike character named "Hippocrates" from Hubbard's science fiction series ''Ole Doc Methuselah''.<ref name="weideman">{{cite news | last =Weideman | first =Paul | title =KLASSICAL EKCLECTIC CHICK | work =[[The Santa Fe New Mexican]] | page =P27 | date =August 13, 2004 }}</ref><ref name="gilbert">{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20040812/news_lz1w12corea1.html|title='This is a very big challenge for me' - Chick Corea 'poured a lot of love and energy' into 'The Adventures of Hippocrates' |work=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]|publisher=Union-Tribune Publishing Co.|date=August 12, 2004|accessdate=2008-06-06|last=Gilbert|first=Andrew }}</ref> Corea would go on to compose another album in 2006, ''[[The Ultimate Adventure]]'', also inspired by and named after a book by Hubbard,<ref name="harrington">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/04/27/AR2006042700728_pf.html|title=Corea's Fresh Riff On an Old Refrain|work=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[The Washington Post Company]] |accessdate=2008-06-06 |date=April 28, 2006|last=Harrington|first=Richard|page=WE10}}</ref> which earned him two [[Grammy Award]]s.<ref>{{cite news | last =Scott | first =Joe | title = Longtime love of music powers pianist Chick Corea | work =Greensboro News & Record | page =GT14 | date =March 13, 2008 }}</ref>
==Reception== {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[Allmusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.allmusic.com/album/r704042 |title=To the Stars - Chick Corea's Elektric Band | AllMusic |first= |last= |work=allmusic.com |year=2011 |accessdate=14 July 2011}}</ref> | rev2 = ''[[The Observer]]'' | rev2Score = {{Rating|3|5}} | rev3 = ''[[The Star-Ledger]]'' | rev3Score = {{Rating|3.5|5}} | rev4 = ''[[The Times]]'' | rev4Score = {{Rating|4|5}} | rev5 = ''[[All About Jazz]]'' | rev5Score = (not rated)<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=14522 |title=Chick Corea Elektric Band | To The Stars |first=Mark |last=Sabbatt ini |work=allaboutjazz.com |year=2011 |accessdate=14 July 2011}}</ref> }} The album reached number eight on [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard'']] magazine's [[Billboard charts|Top Contemporary Jazz]] charts in September 2004,<ref>{{cite news |title =TOP TENS | work =[[The Orlando Sentinel]] | page =12 | date =September 24, 2004 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r704042|pure_url=yes}}|last=Billboard.com © 2006 VNU eMedia, Inc.|title=To the Stars - Charts & Awards - Billboard Albums|work=[[Allmusic]]|publisher=Macrovision Corporation|accessdate=2008-06-05|year=2006}}</ref> and Corea earned a 2004 Grammy Award nomination for instrumental arrangement for the track "The Long Passage".<ref>{{cite news | last =Barrera | first =Sandra | title =They're Wild About Kanye West - Winless at Amas, Now on Top With 10 Grammy Noms | work =[[Daily News of Los Angeles]] | page =U4 | date =December 8, 2004 }}</ref> The album received a rating of three stars from [[Allmusic]],<ref name="allmusicguide">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r704042|pure_url=yes}}|title=To the Stars - Overview|work=[[Allmusic]]|publisher=Macrovision Corporation|accessdate=2008-06-05}}</ref> three stars from ''[[The Observer]]'',<ref name="nicholson">{{cite news | last =Nicholson | first =Stuart | title =The Observer: Observer Music Monthly: Review: 7: Elektric dreams: Don't be scared of prog-jazz-rock, begs Stuart Nicholson | work =[[The Observer]] | date =August 15, 2004}}</ref> three and a half stars from ''[[The Star-Ledger]]'',<ref name="mcmanus">{{cite news | last =McManus | first =Jill | title = Corea's reunited Elektric Band leads new releases - JAZZ GROOVES | work =[[The Star-Ledger]] | page =3 | date =August 29, 2004 }}</ref> and four stars from ''[[The Times]]''.<ref name="shipton">{{cite news | last =Shipton | first =Alyn | title =Chick Corea - Jazz | work =[[The Times]] | publisher =Times Newspapers Limited | date =July 15, 2004 }}</ref> In a review of the work in ''The Washington Post'', Geoffrey Himes writes that "Corea occasionally falls into his old bad habits of jazz-rock fusion excess, substituting frenetic virtuosity for melodic content and emotional connection on tunes such as the album-opening 'Check Blast' and 'Hound of Heaven.'"<ref name="himes" /> Himes highlights Corea's compositions of the seven "Port View" interludes, and calls "Alan Corday" the best piece on the album.<ref name="himes" /> Mike Joyce of ''The Washington Post'' also appreciated the "[[flamenco]]-tinged ballad" of the "Alan Corday" track.<ref>{{cite news | last =Joyce | first =Mike | title =POP MUSIC | work =[[The Washington Post]] | page =C2 | publisher =[[The Washington Post Company]] | date =November 26, 2004 }}</ref> Christopher Blagg of the ''[[Boston Herald]]'' liked "the dense electrified samba of the joyous 'Mistress Luck - The Party'", and commented: "Somewhere L. Ron Hubbard was smiling."<ref>{{cite news | last =Blagg | first =Christopher | title = MUSIC REVIEW - Corea fans thank their lucky `Stars' | work =[[Boston Herald]] | date =November 23, 2004 }}</ref> Bob Young of the ''Boston Herald'' described the album as "music that shifts continually from bright, aggressive jazz fusion to melodic tranquility and back again".<ref name="young" /> James F. Collins gave the album a positive review in ''The Harvard Crimson'', writing: "To The Stars is a testament to his [Corea's] unflagging creativity and is a proud addition to his already expansive discography."<ref name="collins" /> Mike Hobart reviewed the album for ''[[Financial Times]]'', commenting that "once the band had delivered its first unison riff, the music's inspirational source was irrelevant as a fine programme of jazz-fusion poured out".<ref>{{cite news | last =Hobart | first =Mike | title =Chick Corea Electrik Band Barbican, London | work =[[Financial Times]] | page =15 | publisher =The Financial Times Limited | date =July 15, 2004 }}</ref>
In his review of the album, Ben Ratliff of ''[[The New York Times]]'' writes: "I did like the driving, collective muscle of the band, though, very much," but he also describes its aesthetics as "cluttered and gaudy".<ref name="ratliff">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/11/arts/music/11core.html?fta=y|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Jazz Review - Chick Corea Elektric Band: The Cluttered but Valiant Sound of a Space-Age Trip to the Stars|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=2008-06-06|date=November 11, 2004|last=Ratliff|first=Ben}}</ref> For PopMatters, Associate Music Editor Justin Cober-Lake writes: "In many ways, it's a supreme accomplishment with difficult technique passages and broad soundscapes; on the other hand, it's a journey that's too long to take."<ref name="cober">{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/music/reviews/c/coreachick-tothestars.shtml|title=Chick Corea Elektric Band: To the Stars|work=PopMatters Music Review|publisher=www.popmatters.com|accessdate=2008-06-06|last=Cober-Lake|first=Justin}}</ref> In his review of Corea's later work ''The Ultimate Adventure'', Will Friedwald of ''[[The New York Sun]]'' writes: "'To the Stars' was trite, electronic bubblegum music that sounded like a cheesy video-game soundtrack."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nysun.com/arts/back-to-forever/31000/|title=Back to Forever: He's a wily man, that Chick Corea, and he knows the value of contrast and surprise|work=[[The New York Sun]]|date=April 14, 2006|publisher=The New York Sun, One, SL, LLC|accessdate=2008-06-06|last=Friedwald|first=Will}}</ref> Writing in ''The Times'', John Bungey comments that "many of the pieces are straitjacketed into the cosmic concept", concluding his review with: "If you prefer hi-fi to sci-fi, then you will be hoping that Corea leaves the space helmet at home next time."<ref>{{cite news | last =Bungey | first =John | title =Chick Corea Elektric Band - Jazz | work =[[The Times]] | page =The Eye 17 | publisher =Times Newspapers Limited | date =September 4, 2004 }}</ref> John L. Walters gave the album a negative review in ''[[The Guardian]]'', writing that the album "cries out for warning stickers - 'this album contains dangerously high levels of Scientology'", and that it "drags some perfectly fine jazz musicians ... through conceptual purgatory".<ref name="walters">{{cite web|url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/ontheedge/story/0,12830,1337960,00.html|title=Warning: may contain bagpipes: Orchestra Macaroon have mixed conga, piano, sea samples and pipes. Somehow it works|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|date=October 29, 2004|accessdate=2008-06-06|last=Walters|first=John L.}}</ref>

{{Buddhist term | fontsize=100% | title=Ujukatā | pi= ujukatā | sa= | en= rectitude,
straightness,
uprightness }} {{Buddhism|terse=1}} '''Ujukatā''' (Pali) is a [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] term translated as "rectitude", and it is the basis for the following pair of [[Mental factors (Buddhism)|mental factors]] within the [[Theravada]] [[Abhidharma]] teachings: * ''Kāya-ujukatā'' - rectitude of mental body * ''Citta-ujukatā'' - rectitude of consciousness These two mental factors have the characteristic of uprightness of the mental body and consciousness, respectively. ==Definition== Bhikkhu Bodhi states:{{sfn|Bhikkhu Bodhi|2012|loc=Kindle Locations 2377-2380}} :Rectitude is straightness. The twofold rectitude has the characteristic of uprightness of the mental body and consciousness, respectively. Its function is to crush tortuousness of the mental body and consciousness, and its manifestation is non-crookedness. Its proximate cause is the mental body and consciousness. It should be regarded as opposed to hypocrisy and fraudulence, etc., which create crookedness in the mental body and consciousness. Nina van Gorkom explains:{{sfn|van Gorkom|2010|p=229}} :According to the ''[[Dhammasangani]]'' (par 50, 51) this pair of cetasikas consists in straightness and rectitude, being without deflection, twist or crookedness. :The ''[[Atthasālinī]]'' (I, Book I, Part IV, Chapter I, 131) explains that uprightness of cetasikas and of citta crush crookedness and that they are the opponents of the corruptions, such as deception and craftiness, which cause crookedness in mental factors and consciousness. :Uprightness is the opponent of deception and craftiness. ==See also== * [[Mental factors (Buddhism)]] * [[Samadhi (Buddhism)]] == References == ==Sources== * {{citation|last=Bhikkhu Bodhi|year=2012|title=A Comprehensive Manual of Abhidhamma: The Abhidhammattha Sangaha (Vipassana Meditation and the Buddha's Teachings)|publisher= Independent Publishers Group Kindle Edition}} *{{citation|last=van Gorkom|first=Nina|year=2010|title=Cetasikas|publisher=Zolag}} {{Buddhism topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ujukata}} [[Category:Buddhist meditation]] [[Category:Buddhist practices]] [[Category:Buddhist terminology]] [[Category:Buddhist philosophical concepts]]
